We begin to process and catalogue materials from the 2015 season of the Kerry Lodge Archaeology Project, a community-oriented excavation that centers on convict-era features in northern Tasmania. I began attending KLAP in 2016, so the materials we‚Äôre processing are new to me‚Äîand despite my previous experience, I learn a great deal with every batch of finds. We sort through all sorts of sherds, shards, and other bits and pieces; shards of glass from square gin cases, the fragmented remains of ammunition and textured scraps of rubber. Artifacts from each context are sorted by fabric and cleaned. This primes these assemblages to be catalogued. Professor Casella and I weigh, measured and record the form, material, and specific function of each artifact. As we move into contexts of interest, I gain confidence in dealing with materials that I never encountered during my time in cultural resources management, from the thick, iridescent glass sherds of a panel mirror to an intact gunflint. As we set to inventorying each batch, the materials are cleaned and set out to dry overnight.
Ceramics and glass from one context, cleaned and waiting until next week. Photo by author, 2017.
Over the next week, the process will continue‚Äîand as I clean, catalogue, and photograph, I become increasingly confident in my capacity to gather my own data. ¬†The history I hope to plumb is a delicate and dark one; however, I feel the benefits of my research outweigh its risks. Historical attitudes have shaped current narratives surrounding mental illness. If we can dredge up a bit more of the past, we can contextualize the difficulties, stigma, and challenges faced by neurodivergent individuals today. Perhaps one day I can transform this unique focus into an outreach project with its own therapeutic value. For now, I have to settle for¬† building the core research from which I may someday be able to build such a project--and really, that feels nothing like settling at all. To learn more about my research on and interest in the nineteenth-century lunatic asylum and other historic institutions--from penitentiaries to boarding schools--join me on researchgate or twitter.
  Unfortunately, the research I‚Äôve outlined today‚Äîand many more projects like it, undertaken by aspiring and early career scholars, heritage-workers, and field-archaeologists‚Äîis currently struggling to survive. The University of Manchester Administration has recently proposed a massive cut to the to its senior faculty. Among the of 171 senior staff members slated for termination, professors from the archaeology department have been uniquely targeted. Come next July, we will lose four of our eight full-time lecturers, already down from a full twelve the last year. This action (justified under the unsubstantiated rhetoric of ‚Äúimproving the student experience‚Äù) cuts an already strained department in half, and will leave use well beyond functioning capacity. Several stakeholders have approached the University, which has now sworn to provide ‚Äúno further answers‚Äù to concerns voiced in protestation of these unjustified cuts from within the institution. However, If you can spare just a moment, please sign on to this petition protesting these actions‚Äîif you have more time, the faculty and students would be very grateful if you would send an email or letter of support (or gentle admonishment) to Dame Nancy Rothwell, whose contact details I will list below. ¬†You can learn more about our cause (and other ways to support it) here. If you‚Äôre interested in how this process is negatively affecting aspiring researchers, check out this post from another doctoral candidate in our department. Contacts to Protest Cuts to University of Manchester Arts and Archaeology Staff Professor Dame Nancy Rothwell President and Vice-Chancellor University of Manchester Oxford Road Manchester M13 9PL president@manchester.ac.uk Professor Keith Brown Dean of Humanities University of Manchester Oxford Road Manchester M13 9PL Keith.brown@manchester.ac.uk Mr Edward Astle Chair of the Board of Governors University of Manchester Oxford Road Manchester M13 9PL chair@manchester.ac.uk

item.title: Putting the Experimental Into Archaeology!
item.dc:creator: c.walton
item.content:encoded:
We are archaeology students from Cardiff University undertaking a month‚Äôs fieldwork placement at Butser Ancient Farm. The farm, situated not far from Portsmouth in Hampshire, is well known as a site for conducting experimental archaeology. As part of the national Day of Archaeology, the site organised a ‚ÄòTry it Day‚Äô, where members of the public could participate in a variety of activities ranging from wattle fencing to stone baking bread. Our activity was to build and test a functional Roman style onager, rectifying the problems found in our first attempt.
The onager, named after its donkey-like kick when it fires, is a siege engine developed in ancient Greece and later adopted by the Romans, which sources its power entirely through torsion.¬†The basic framework for the onager is constructed from 4‚Äùx4‚Äù timber around a 48‚Äù x 27‚Äù frame with a 46‚Äù arm.¬†The site‚Äôs original onager, which measures an approximate 10ft in height, faced two key issues surrounding both its ease of use and capability. Firstly, as the rope bundle would not hold high torsion, the siege engine would not fire particularly far in proportion to its large size. Secondly, those who used the original onager faced tremendous trouble cocking it to fire effectively. To conquer the torsion issue, pins would need to be installed to secure the torsion rods in place and prevent the bundle slipping. Furthermore, to amend the struggle of cocking the firing arm, a ratchet system would be installed to crank back the firing arm which would then be fired using a pin on the end of a string.
Even though we faced a fair few bumps during the construction of the onager, we managed to construct it just in time to fire on Try it Day! The catapult was set up, we were all dressed up, and the rotten apples were just waiting to be fired. However, there was one problem we were unprepared for; the sheer popularity of the onager amongst the kids. The system worked, firing time and time again in succession, achieving a greater distance each time as the torsion was further racked up. Then disaster struck, in the form of a miscreant child cracking the dowel on the firing mechanism. Halted for two hours, we scrambled to find an alternative but safe firing mechanism which would still let the children participate. As the sky broke and heavens opened, we settled for cocking the arm by hand and pinning it through two eyes screwed into the frame of the onager. Regardless of the rain, the children kept in high spirits and carried on participating. Interestingly, the rain aided us in our efforts by lubricating the bundle and dowels, in turn allowing torsion to be again increased, flinging apples further and further until it reached the end of the paddock.
Overall, the project was a success and proved popular amongst kids of all ages, successfully introducing them to what you might term ‚Äòexperiential‚Äô archaeology. Furthermore, once the dowel on the cocking mechanism is replaced, we aim to conduct some experimentation around the firing of the onager ‚Äì testing different lengths of sling, and subsequently different firing arcs, to see which is deemed the most effective and efficient method of catapulting projectiles.
Hannah Rock and Lewis Beck

item.title: Diversity in Archaeological Work: One Archaeologist's Journey
item.dc:creator: ana.silkatcheva
item.content:encoded:
The mission of the Day of Archaeology project has been to show the diversity of work done by archaeologists around the world as a group, and what a success it has been! In this post, I want to demonstrate that a single archaeologist can have diversity in work throughout their career too, and to emphasise that there is (paid) work to be found in this field. I started my career with a focus on the archaeology of the Byzantine and Islamic periods in the country of Jordan. While I am still on this chosen path of mine and continue to be active in both excavation and research, I spent the actual Day of Archaeology this year writing a conservation management plan for a cemetery founded at the end of the 19th century in Australia! I write this post especially for those younger people who might be interested in pursuing their interest in archaeology as a career but who may be discouraged (either by themselves or through the warnings of elders and peers) by the myth that there is no work in archaeology. The skills one develops as an archaeologist are transferrable. I don‚Äôt necessarily mean to jobs in the mainstream, though that is also true (but you just might have to try extra hard to convince employers of that!) ‚Äì I mean in the field itself, and in related fields. With hard work and effort, supported by flexibility, a dedication to networking, a little bit of entrepreneurship, and of course (as with anything else), luck, an archaeologist can find work across a range of interesting projects and disciplines while getting paid.

What I do now

On the Day of Archaeology 2017, I was ensconced at my desk in a company office in Sydney, working as a heritage consultant for a private firm. I was analysing and writing about significant views to, from, and within a historically significant cemetery for a conservation management plan. This would become the principal guiding document for the preservation of the heritage values of the site through the cemetery‚Äôs continued operation. While it is important for archaeologists to excavate sites for the purpose of research or salvage, it is just as critical to manage places of historical significance so that they may be enjoyed by subsequent generations. This is where the closely related field of cultural heritage management comes in: caretakers of sites, places and buildings need policies to guide them in balancing future development and changes with conservation. As a heritage consultant with the company I have been working for, I have spent more of my time looking at architectural heritage than archaeology. But I like to say that understanding the modern built environment is just another way of applying archaeological skills and thinking. When analysing the fabric of a building or site ‚Äì even a modern one ‚Äì to understand its history and development, the changes it has undergone can be considered like a deposition of layers, each related to a particular event. This is the physical evidence. In Australia, as the built environment is relatively modern, an understanding of the evolution of a building or site ‚Äì and the people it was associated with ‚Äì can be supported through historical documents like original architects‚Äô plans, early maps, photographs, newspaper articles, and other documentary evidence. Together, physical and documentary evidence form a picture of how the building or site was in its original state, and what changes have been made throughout its life. Based on this understanding of the building or site, a heritage consultant is able to assess the historical significance of the building or site as a whole and of its various parts. This, in turn, guides the development of conservation policies: what is most significant to be kept, what can be changed through subsequent development, and how this can be done. In various countries, heritage buildings and sites are legally protected, so no proposed changes can proceed without the professional opinion and assessment of a heritage consultant. In this way, archaeology and history have a clear and important link to the modern world.

How I got here, and what I have done in the past (and continue to do alongside my current job‚Ä¶)

As I mentioned earlier, I didn‚Äôt start out in cultural heritage management or even looking at architecture, and it probably won‚Äôt be the last thing I do my career. My journey in archaeology began traditionally enough, and as I have progressed through life in archaeology, I have had the privilege to make many interesting stops along the way. Here is a condensed history of my pathway as an archaeologist so far, which shows the various ways one can engage with this fascinating and relevant field. I began my studies in Australia in Classical Archaeology and quickly understood that that well-trodden area was not for me ‚Äì as it was my only exposure, at that point, to what I thought I wanted to pursue as a career path, this realisation was heavily discouraging. But all was saved when I went on my first field school in Jordan, working on an Islamic-Byzantine site near the Dead Sea. I fell in love with, amongst other things (!), the beautiful, colourfully glazed pottery sherds that were common throughout the stratigraphy: I had discovered that I wanted to focus on Islamic material culture. [caption id="attachment_29293" align="aligncenter" width="478"] Islamic ceramics on display at the Museum at the Lowest Place on Earth. Photo by A. Silkatcheva.[/caption] I ended up moving to Jordan not long after this foundational experience, and lived there for a few years. During this time I continued working on excavations at the same site and another Islamic site nearby, an extensively preserved Medieval sugar factory, with a small team under the aegis of the Hellenic Society for Near Eastern Studies. The sugar factory became one of my major projects, and I continue to contribute to it in various ways from afar. Here, and at the associated new regional museum, the Museum at the Lowest Place on Earth, I learned about my beloved Islamic pottery from an expert in the field, and as the project team was always small, I also gained all the field skills an archaeologist needs. Through life and work in Jordan, I became proficient in colloquial Arabic. [caption id="attachment_29291" align="aligncenter" width="456"] The site of Tawahin al-Sukkar, a Medieval Islamic sugar factory south of the Dead Sea in Jordan. Photo by A. Silkatcheva.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_29292" align="aligncenter" width="461"] The Museum at the Lowest Place on Earth, south of the Dead Sea in Jordan. Photo by A. Silkatcheva.[/caption] I had always known that I wanted a career in research and to complete my PhD, so while in Jordan I continued my studies through a research master‚Äôs degree at a university in Australia. Through the suggestion of my supervisor, my focus became Byzantine/Islamic mosaics in a small sub-region of Jordan, and specifically their geometric motifs. It is true that languages ‚Äì especially reading skills ‚Äì are important for research, and here I was helped by the formal studies in modern and ancient languages I had undertaken during my first degree. Mostly, I funded life through a generous research grant and remote work as a research assistant back home. But as I established myself in the archaeological community in Jordan, I was invited to work on other interesting projects locally. One new aspect to my skills became the technical side of academic editing and publishing as related to archaeology and similar fields. On contracts to existing and new colleagues, I assisted in various ways with the preparation of monographs, translations, and conference proceedings on wide-ranging topics related to understanding the past. Eventually, circumstances brought me back to Australia, where I knew in advance I would have to remain for an extended time. I had heard that archaeological work here was scarce, and archaeological work on anything related to my research interests even more so. Nonetheless, I tried, and after some time in limbo, appreciation for my language skills saw me appointed as the librarian for the Australian Archaeological Institute at Athens at its Sydney headquarters, a position I continue to hold today alongside my consulting role. While the essence of my work is administrative support for researchers, it is certainly a great privilege to contribute to the management of one of the most important and extensive archaeological libraries in the country and thereby gaining exposure to many interesting publications, old and new, in the field of Mediterranean archaeology. One year, I briefly turned my attention to re-organising the Institute‚Äôs library at its office in Greece. I‚Äôve supplemented this work with a variety of other projects. With my experience in editing and publishing, I offered to digitise the back issues of an Australian archaeological journal for online publication and was awarded a contract to do so. I continued my editing work for colleagues I had met in Jordan. I contributed my excavation skills on project-based contracts for local commercial archaeology companies. My archaeological illustration skills led me to employment on a project to document multilingual sandstone inscriptions made in the contemporary past by internees at a major Quarantine Station. I assisted in archival historical research to support that same project and its associated public history publication. I leant my skills in photography and understanding of colonial architecture to a close colleague‚Äôs heritage documentation project in India. And I put my Arabic to good use by developing and teaching my own course, Colloquial Arabic for Archaeologists, at the Centre for Classical and Near Eastern Studies of Australia. It has been important to me to pass on my knowledge and facilitate other professionals, students, and volunteers working in my chosen field and in my chosen region of specialisation. I mentioned earlier that my goal has always been a career in research and therefore I needed, and wanted, to complete my PhD. And I have also known for a long time that my primary research interests lay in the material culture of Islamic societies. This is a tricky goal to pursue in Australia, as there are no universities that have either coursework or research resources in this specialisation. So, I will have to pursue the continuation of my education elsewhere. In the meantime, I have aimed to engage with my research specialisation in other ways. I have continued writing and I am looking for a good avenue to publish my master‚Äôs dissertation. But I realised that I would need to network more broadly and gain other experience. I began a second master‚Äôs degree, by coursework this time, in museum and heritage studies, to broaden my skills and expertise. The capstone of this degree was an internship at an institution chosen by the student. Strategic thinking led me to explore opportunities at museums with major collections of Islamic art and archaeological artefacts, and soon I flew off to complete my internship in the curatorial department of a museum renowned in this field. Here I worked closely with my favourite Islamic ceramics, applying my knowledge of pottery already familiar to me and gaining exposure to new material. I met supportive new colleagues, and this amazing experience led to an invitation to return to the museum and continue my work on the ceramics collection as a curatorial consultant on contract. Luckily, my existing employers were happy to support this temporary segue into my other career path, especially as it meant I would develop new skills that would be transferrable to the work I was already doing. Working in a formal capacity with my chosen subject and artefacts has been the highlight of my career so far! And, finally, of course, how did I end up in my role as a heritage consultant? It was a happy accident which happened as a result of my participation in the mentoring program run by the International Council on Monuments and Sites (Australia), available to students in my master‚Äôs program in museum and heritage studies. Importantly, and to repeat my words above, a career in archaeology has been possible for me not only through my own efforts, but also by getting out there and getting to know people in the field, by thinking a little bit outside the square, and by being flexible and open to change and variety. And as always, I couldn't have made it without some luck thrown in as well.

What this means for aspiring archaeologists

All this is to say that it is possible to have a career in archaeology, and although it will probably not be straightforward and easy, I can guarantee it will be varied and interesting! There is work available for people with archaeological skills, experience, background, and mindset. While a career in this field may not be as ‚Äòstable‚Äô as one in, say, bank management, with your skills and training ‚Äì which can be directly or indirectly related to your chosen field ‚Äì you can add value to interesting projects, organisations, and companies, large and small, and be valued for your contribution in return. It is even possible to find a full-time job in the related field of cultural heritage management (whether it‚Äôs built heritage like I do or commercial archaeology), which is key to tying the significance of the past to the modern day.

item.title: The Roots of Coincidence
item.dc:creator: apialewska
item.content:encoded: P.R. Ofiarski   ¬† Janos Szekeres otworzy≈Ç zegarek kieszonkowy i spojrza≈Ç na ustawienie wskaz√≥wek na tarczy, kt√≥re wskazywa≈Çy godzinƒô 16.50. Wiƒôc jeszcze dziesiƒôƒá minut, pomy≈õla≈Ç i schowa≈Ç przedmiot do kieszonki kamizelki. Zawsze mia≈Ç w zwyczaju przychodziƒá wcze≈õniej na um√≥wione spotkania, ale gdy ju≈º przybywa≈Ç na miejsce, plu≈Ç sobie w brodƒô, ≈ºe m√≥g≈Ç jeszcze spƒôdziƒá te kilkana≈õcie minut w zaciszu domu, na czytaniu jakiej≈õ ksiƒÖ≈ºki albo serwowaniu dalej w echonecie. Niemniej, zawsze wpajano mu zasadƒô, ≈ºe lepiej przyj≈õƒá dziesiƒôƒá minut przed ni≈º dziesiƒôƒá minut po i niezale≈ºnie, od sytuacji, zawsze pojawia≈Ç siƒô przed wyznaczonƒÖ godzinƒÖ. Mƒô≈ºczyzna wypu≈õci≈Ç z ust tylko powietrze, majƒÖc ochotƒô zapaliƒá papierosa. Niemniej, pok√≥j, w kt√≥rym w≈Ça≈õnie czeka≈Ç na przyjƒôcie przez Talisa Usi‚Äônthar zdawa≈Ç siƒô nie byƒá przystosowany dla palaczy. Raz, ≈ºe nie by≈Ço ≈ºadnej popielniczki. Dwa, sam wystr√≥j wykazywa≈Ç, ≈ºe to do≈õƒá eleganckie miejsce. Meble oraz krzes≈Ça, na kt√≥rych siedzieli petenci, zrobione by≈Ço z najprawdziwszego dƒôbu, a nie jakiego≈õ substytutu, tak popularnego w tych czasach, a na dodatek, siedziska obite by≈Çy czerwonym materia≈Çem. Na ≈õcianach wisia≈Çy obrazy, prawdopodobnie r√≥wnie≈º orygina≈Çy, a nie kopie. Akurat tego Janos nie by≈Ç w stanie stwierdziƒá, gdy≈º nie by≈Ç historykiem sztuki, a archeologiem. Gdyby w pomieszczeniu znajdowa≈Çy siƒô jakie≈õ artefakty, kt√≥re formƒÖ przypomina≈Çyby jakie≈õ artefakty sprzed wiek√≥w, nie mia≈Çby problem√≥w z rozpoznaniem ich autentyczno≈õci. Tymczasem, w tym przypadku, nie by≈Ç w og√≥le w stanie specjalnie wykazaƒá siƒô umiejƒôtno≈õciami. Mƒô≈ºczyzna w ko≈Ñcu nie wytrzyma≈Ç presji i wsta≈Ç z krzes≈Ça, podchodzƒÖc do lustra, by przyjrzeƒá siƒô, czy nie przyniesie wstydu swojƒÖ aparycjƒÖ. Dok≈Çadnie przyjrza≈Ç siƒô twarzy, kt√≥rƒÖ mia≈Ç nadziejƒô, starannie ogoli≈Ç przed przyj≈õciem na spotkanie. Szczƒô≈õliwie, nie osta≈Ç siƒô nawet jeden w≈Ços. Cieszy≈Ç siƒô, ≈ºe kilka dni temu w ko≈Ñcu uda≈Ç siƒô do fryzjera. W≈Çosy zazwyczaj nie przeszkadza≈Çy mu w pracy, niemniej, co≈õ go pokusi≈Ço, by w ko≈Ñcu siƒô ostrzyc na kr√≥tko. Gdy po powrocie dowiedzia≈Ç siƒô, ≈ºe zosta≈Ç zaproszony do Dzielnicy Kryszta≈Çowej, wizyta fryzjerska okaza≈Ça siƒô byƒá ≈õwietnym pomys≈Çem. Sprawdzi≈Ç r√≥wnie≈º, czy po≈õr√≥d tych czarnych w≈Ços√≥w nie znalaz≈Ç siƒô ≈ºaden siwy. Nie, by spodziewa≈Ç siƒô jakiego≈õ znale≈∫ƒá. Mia≈Ç w ko≈Ñcu dopiero trzydzie≈õci trzy lata, ale strze≈ºonego, Pan B√≥g strze≈ºe, jak mawia≈Ça jego matka. Poprawi≈Ç brƒÖzowƒÖ kamizelkƒô zrobionƒÖ z zamszu, kt√≥ra mia≈Ça byƒá wzorowana na tych, kt√≥re by≈Çy modne w latach trzydziestych XX wieku, podobnie z resztƒÖ jak bia≈Ça koszula na zapinki, szare spodnie oraz wylakierowane, brƒÖzowe buty. Po≈õr√≥d badaczy przesz≈Ço≈õci przyjƒô≈Ço siƒô w≈Ça≈õnie ubieraƒá w ten spos√≥b, gdy≈º kompozycja stroju z tego okresu historycznego mia≈Ça uchodziƒá za przejaw prawdziwej elegancji i wygody. Nie by≈Ço to jednak regu≈ÇƒÖ, gdy≈º wszystko zale≈ºa≈Ço od przynale≈ºno≈õci obywatelskiej. Inaczej ubierali siƒô badacze z Federacji, inaczej z Cesarstwa, a jeszcze innƒÖ modƒô uznawano w Kalifatach Azjatyckich. Janos, zadowolony z oglƒôdzin, usiad≈Ç z powrotem na krze≈õle. Nie minƒô≈Ça jednak nawet sekunda, gdy wsta≈Ç, gdy≈º nagle otworzy≈Çy siƒô drzwi, z kt√≥rych wy≈Çoni≈Ç siƒô Talis z La‚Äôu. Pomimo tego, ≈ºe archeolog nie interesowa≈Ç siƒô specjalnie koteriami, rozpozna≈Ç w niebieskosk√≥rym przewodniczƒÖcego Rady Wygna≈Ñczej. Oboje wydawali siƒô byƒá w dobrym humorze, gdy≈º Tha‚Äôlitanin u≈õmiechnƒÖ≈Ç siƒô do s≈Ç√≥w Alhara i pokiwa≈Ç z zadowoleniem g≈ÇowƒÖ. Nie trwa≈Ço d≈Çugo, nim Talis zoczy≈Ç Janosa. Obr√≥ci≈Ç siƒô w jego stronƒô i spokojnym krokiem podszed≈Ç do niego, ju≈º wyciƒÖgajƒÖc rƒôkƒô: - Doktorze, cieszƒô siƒô, ≈ºe pana widzƒô- zaczƒô≈Ça od uprzejmo≈õci g≈Çowa koterii Usi‚Äônthar. Janos z grzeczno≈õci poda≈Ç rƒôkƒô. Tha‚Äôlitanin jednak kontynuowa≈Ç.- Proszƒô o wybaczenie, ≈ºe musia≈Ç Pan tyle czekaƒá, nie mniej, musia≈Çem siƒô rozm√≥wiƒá jeszcze z przewodniczƒÖcym T‚Äôukiem. - Proszƒô siƒô tym nie przejmowaƒá, nie czeka≈Çem zbyt d≈Çugo- odpowiedzia≈Ç k≈Çamstwem cz≈Çowiek, zabierajƒÖc z powrotem rƒôkƒô.- Nie mniej, jestem zaskoczony, ≈ºe tak szybko nalega≈Ç Pan na spotkanie. - Bo i sprawa nag≈Ça- przyzna≈Ç Talis, wzdychajƒÖc lekko. Po chwili jednak wr√≥ci≈Ç mu dobry nastr√≥j.- Nim to, chcia≈Çbym, by doktor pozna≈Ç Alhara T‚Äôuka, przewodniczƒÖcego Rady Wygna≈Ñczej. Panie przewodniczƒÖcy, oto pan Janos Szekeres, doktor archeologii ze specjalizacjƒÖ w III Wojnie Ziemskiej. Naukowiec podni√≥s≈Ç brew, jakby zdajƒÖc sobie sprawƒô z tego, ≈ºe Tha‚Äôlitanin powinien w≈Ça≈õnie zaczƒÖƒá od przedstawienia swojego go≈õcia. Janos przyjrza≈Ç mu siƒô z bliska dopiero, gdy skierowa≈Ç swoje kroki w stronƒô La‚Äôu. By≈Ç to ju≈º niem≈Çody mƒô≈ºczyzna, bez w≈Ços√≥w na g≈Çowie i z rozwiniƒôtymi guzami pr√≥≈ºniowymi przy szyi, co, wedle standard√≥w tej niebieskosk√≥rej rasy, ≈õwiadczy≈Çy o naprawdƒô d≈Çugim wieku. PrzewodniczƒÖcy ubrany by≈Ç ≈º√≥≈Çte szaty o szerokich rƒôkawach i wyciƒôciu na kroku, a na ramiona narzucony zielony p≈Çaszcz z symbolem przedstawiajƒÖcym trzy inteligentne rasy na tle s≈Ço≈Ñca. Janos zdawa≈Ç sobie sprawƒô, ≈ºe by≈Ço to nawiƒÖzanie do fresku, mieszczƒÖcego siƒô na suficie siedziby Rady Wygna≈Ñczej. Talis r√≥wnie≈º by≈Ç ubrany w podobne szaty, niemniej zamiast zielonego, p≈Çaszcz by≈Ç czarno czerwony z symbolem pszczo≈Çy, po≈ºerajƒÖcego sw√≥j w≈Çasny ogon, czyli emblematu koterii Usi‚Äônthar. W chwili, w kt√≥rej archeolog znalaz≈Ç siƒô przy Alharze, La‚Äôu poda≈Ç mu rƒôkƒô. Zaskoczy≈Ço to cz≈Çowieka, gdy≈º my≈õla≈Ç, ≈ºe to przewodniczƒÖcy jest osobƒÖ, kt√≥rej nale≈ºy oddaƒá szacunek, ale zdaje siƒô, ≈ºe zasady etykiety by≈Çy zupe≈Çnie inne po≈õr√≥d Wygna≈Ñc√≥w. Naukowiec nie chcƒÖc obraziƒá swojego gospodarza, poda≈Ç rƒôkƒô niebieskosk√≥remu. - To zaszczyt spotkaƒá kogo≈õ, kto wciƒÖ≈º uprawia tak egzotycznƒÖ naukƒô, jakƒÖ jest archeologia- powiedzia≈Ç Alhar, ≈õciskajƒÖc rƒôkƒô badacza.- Proszƒô o wybaczenie, ale czy jest Pan wyk≈ÇadowcƒÖ na uczelni czy wolnym strzelcem? - Przyjemno≈õƒá po mojej stronie- odpowiedzia≈Ç naukowiec, puszczajƒÖc rƒôkƒô przewodniczƒÖcego.- Jedynie doktoryzowa≈Çem siƒô na Uniwersytecie Tokijskim w Cesarstwie Japo≈Ñskim, ju≈º wcze≈õniej prowadzƒÖc dzia≈Çalno≈õƒá us≈ÇugowƒÖ z zakresu archeologii. Jednak, stosunkowo niedawno zaczƒÖ≈Çem swojƒÖ dzia≈Çalno≈õƒá na Keplerze, u≈ºyczajƒÖc swojej wiedzy i umiejƒôtno≈õci koteriom. - Todai, no proszƒô- La‚Äôu ewidentnie by≈Ç zaskoczony, podobnie z resztƒÖ jak Janos, w chwili, gdy przewodniczƒÖcy u≈ºy≈Ç potocznej nazwy na uniwersytet w Tokio.- Uczƒôszcza≈Çem tam na fakultety z politologii, nim jeszcze objƒÖ≈Çem tron przewodniczƒÖcego. Trudno znale≈∫ƒá lepsze miejsce je≈õli chodzi o wydarzenia poprzedzajƒÖce i nastƒôpujƒÖce po III Wojnie Ziemskiej. Nie mniej, mam nadziejƒô, ≈ºe to w≈Ça≈õnie Kepler najbardziej spe≈Çni Pana oczekiwania. - R√≥wnie≈º chcia≈Çbym w to wierzyƒá- odpowiedzia≈Ç archeolog, pozwalajƒÖc sobie na sztuczny u≈õmiech.- Nie mniej, nie chcƒô zajmowaƒá ju≈º Panu czasu, a my≈õlƒô, ≈ºe radny Usi‚Äônthar te≈º chcia≈Çby przedstawiƒá swojƒÖ propozycjƒô. - Oczywi≈õcie, nie mam zamiaru przeszkadzaƒá Panu w pracy- odpowiedzia≈Ç Alhar, po raz kolejny podajƒÖc rƒôkƒô.- ≈ªyczƒô mi≈Çego dnia. Jak i r√≥wnie≈º tobie Talisie. Dziƒôkujƒô, ≈ºe po≈õwiƒôci≈Çe≈õ starcowi sw√≥j czas. - Nie zapomnij o obiedzie- odpowiedzia≈Ç opryskliwie Tha‚Äôlitanin, ale wciƒÖ≈º majƒÖc u≈õmiech na twarzy. - W razie czego, przypomnij mi jeszcze o nim. Wiesz, ta skleroza. Gdy tylko Janos pu≈õci≈Ç d≈Ço≈Ñ przewodniczƒÖcego, niebieskosk√≥ry podszed≈Ç w stronƒô windy i wsiad≈Ç do niej, wracajƒÖc do swoich spraw. Gdy tylko La‚Äôu zniknƒÖ≈Ç za srebrnymi wrotami, Talis zaprosi≈Ç gestem rƒôki Janosa do pokoju, z kt√≥rego przed chwilƒÖ wyszed≈Ç. - Macie do≈õƒá osobliwe obyczaje. Stwierdzi≈Ç Janos, wchodzƒÖc do pomieszczenia i przyglƒÖdajƒÖc siƒô jego wnƒôtrzu. Pomimo, ≈ºe budynek by≈Ç zbudowany z kryszta≈Çu solarnego, wnƒôtrze nie by≈Ço zrobione z tego≈º minera≈Çu. Posiada≈Ç metalowe ≈õciany, do kt√≥rych przymocowano lampy plazmowe, kt√≥re regulowane by≈Çy przy wej≈õciu. Na ≈õcianach nie by≈Ço ≈ºadnych obraz√≥w, a jedynie ekran echonetowy. Umeblowanie sk≈Çada≈Ço siƒô z kilku foteli, kanapy, sto≈Çu oraz rega≈Ç√≥w z r√≥≈ºnymi dokumentami oraz ksiƒÖ≈ºkami. - Co masz na my≈õli?- spyta≈Ç siƒô Talis, zapraszajƒÖc gestem rƒôki do zasiƒÖdniƒôcia na fotelu. - W kwestii etykiety dyplomatycznej. Pomimo tego, ≈ºe rozmawia≈Çem z przewodniczƒÖcym waszej rady, nie musia≈Çem siƒô do niego zwracaƒá tytularnie, nie musia≈Çem co chwila oddawaƒá mu honor√≥w, co jest normalne po≈õr√≥d polityk√≥w w Federacji- zaczƒÖ≈Ç powoli wyliczaƒá badacz, zasiadajƒÖc we wskazanym mu miejscu.- Przypomina≈Ço mi to bardziej relacjƒô narzeczony-przysz≈Çy ojciec. - Ciekawe spostrze≈ºenie- stwierdzi≈Ç radny, r√≥wnie≈º siadajƒÖc.- Warte p√≥≈∫niejszego wspomnienia. Niemniej masz racjƒô, ale jednocze≈õnie jej nie majƒÖc. Przede wszystkim, Alhar nie uprawia polityki, jest tylko str√≥≈ºem zgromadze≈Ñ. Nawet nie jest ju≈º cz≈Çonkiem swojej koterii, by nie reprezentowaƒá spojrzenia swoich podw≈Çadnych. StƒÖd, to pozycja czysto honorowa. Inna sprawa, ≈ºe hierarchiƒô zostawiamy w≈Ça≈õnie na zgromadzenia, by na co dzie≈Ñ posiadaƒá relacje‚Ä¶ hm‚Ä¶ kole≈ºe≈Ñskie. Oczywi≈õcie, wewnƒÖtrz koterii mo≈ºe byƒá r√≥≈ºnie to prowadzone: jedne uznajƒÖ tytularno≈õƒá wojskowƒÖ, inne dworskƒÖ, a jeszcze inne nawet socjalistycznƒÖ, zwracajƒÖc siƒô do siebie per ‚Äûtowarzyszu‚Äù. - Marzenie Marksa i Engelsa spe≈Çni≈Ço siƒô dopiero w sferach kosmicznych- za≈ºartowa≈Ç Janos.- I pomy≈õleƒá, ≈ºe kiedy≈õ takie okre≈õlenie by≈Çoby r√≥wnoznaczne z fantazjƒÖ. Ale chyba nie wezwa≈Çe≈õ mnie tu po to, by≈õmy wsp√≥lnie czytali ‚ÄûManifest‚Äù, prawda? - Masz racjƒô, ale nim to, mo≈ºe przynajmniej czego≈õ siƒô napijesz?- zaproponowa≈Ç Tha‚Äôlitanin. - CzarnƒÖ kawƒô, sypanƒÖ, dwie ≈Çy≈ºeczki cukru- odpowiedzia≈Ç spokojnie archeolog, k≈ÇadƒÖc d≈Çonie na porƒôczy fotela. Talis kiwnƒÖ≈Ç g≈ÇowƒÖ i przez interkom zam√≥wi≈Ç wybrany przez naukowca nap√≥j, samemu decydujƒÖc siƒô na herbatƒô. Gdy dosta≈Ç potwierdzenie parzenia herbaty i kawy, radny roz≈Ço≈ºy≈Ç siƒô uspokojony na fotelu. - Nie przed≈Çu≈ºajƒÖc ju≈º- zaczƒÖ≈Ç powoli Tha‚Äôlitanin.- Stosunkowo niedawno uda≈Ço mi siƒô zdobyƒá pewien artefakt z czas√≥w III Wojny Ziemskiej o nieznanym charakterze, przynajmniej wedle wstƒôpnych ekspertyz miejscowych pasjonat√≥w tego typu przedmiot√≥w. Swoim kszta≈Çtem przypomina trumnƒô, kt√≥ra wymaga zasilenia przez bli≈ºej nieokre≈õlone ≈∫r√≥d≈Ço energii. Niestety, wszyscy moi in≈ºynierowie za≈ÇamujƒÖ w tym momencie rƒôce, gdy≈º brakuje najbardziej podstawowych danych na temat tego urzƒÖdzenia. A takich jest w stanie uzyskaƒá jedynie archeolog. - Chyba rozumiem do czego to zmierza, Talis- stwierdzi≈Ç Janos, wyra≈∫nie siƒô u≈õmiechajƒÖc.- Chcia≈Çby≈õ, bym ze swoimi lud≈∫mi zajƒÖ≈Ç siƒô analizƒÖ typologicznƒÖ tego urzƒÖdzenia, by≈õcie mogli go uruchomiƒá. - B≈ÇƒÖd- zaprzeczy≈Ç Talis.- Nie jestem g≈Çupcem, Janos, wiem, ≈ºe tego typu urzƒÖdzenia sƒÖ niebezpieczne nawet unieruchomione, a gdy zostanƒÖ aktywowane, mo≈ºe byƒá jeszcze gorzej. Na razie chcia≈Çbym siƒô dowiedzieƒá po prostu natury tego artefaktu: co to jest, skƒÖd pochodzi, jak dzia≈Ça, czym jest zasilane oraz czy znajduje siƒô na Li≈õcie. O jego przysz≈Ço≈õci zadecydujƒô po badaniach. Po tych s≈Çowach do pokoju wszed≈Ç Klaus, sekretarz radnego, kt√≥ry przyni√≥s≈Ç na tacy zam√≥wione napoje. Postawi≈Ç je przed rozmawiajƒÖcymi, skinƒÖ≈Ç g≈ÇowƒÖ i wyszed≈Ç z pokoju. Po chwili ciszy, g≈Ços zabra≈Ç archeolog. - Oczywi≈õcie, jestem w stanie przeprowadziƒá takie badania- Janos wziƒÖ≈Ç do rƒôki kubek z kawƒÖ.- Niemniej, nim je rozpocznƒô, potrzebujƒô dokumentacji odnalezienia tego przedmiotu, zawierajƒÖcƒÖ miejsce odkrycia, osobƒô, kt√≥ra natrafi≈Ça na ten artefakt, spos√≥b transportu i danych o wszystkich ≈ºyjƒÖcych jeszcze jawnych w≈Ça≈õcicielach. Druga rzecz, w chwili, gdy zadanie zostaje zlecone archeologowi, aby by≈Çy one prowadzone legalnie, trzeba nadaƒá artefaktowi numer katalogowy i zg≈Çosiƒá do miejscowego konserwatora zabyt‚Ä¶ - Na Keplerze nie ma ≈ºadnego konserwatora zabytk√≥w, doktorze- przerwa≈Ç Talis, kosztujƒÖc swojej herbaty.- Uznaj to za zlecenie prywatne, bez prowadzenia waszej wewnƒôtrznej dokumentacji przed pr√≥bƒÖ uruchomienia. - Namawiasz mnie do czarnej archeologii- stwierdzi≈Ç doktor, podnoszƒÖc brew do g√≥ry.- To niezgodne z prawem. - Czyim? Federacji? Cesarstwa? Republiki?- prychnƒÖ≈Ç radny, odk≈ÇadajƒÖc fili≈ºankƒô z herbatƒÖ.- Obecnie znajdujesz siƒô na terytorium wolnym od wszelkich praw, wiƒôc mo≈ºesz ominƒÖƒá ten krok. Czy raczej, przenie≈õƒá go na p√≥≈∫niej, je≈õli etyka zawodowa nie daje ci spokoju. - Uwa≈ºaj, Talis- Janos r√≥wnie≈º od≈Ço≈ºy≈Ç kubek na st√≥≈Ç, zachowujƒÖc du≈ºe pok≈Çady spokoju.- To, ≈ºe ≈ºyjƒô dziƒôki tobie nie znaczy, ≈ºe mo≈ºesz decydowaƒá o mojej moralno≈õci. WciƒÖ≈º obowiƒÖzuje mnie prawo galaktyczne, kt√≥re jasno m√≥wi co nale≈ºy robiƒá ze wszystkimi znaleziskami z czas√≥w III Wojny Ziemskiej. - Znam ten rozdzia≈Ç - przyzna≈Ç Talis.- Niemniej, jeden z artyku≈Ç√≥w m√≥wi jasno, ≈ºe tyczy siƒô to wszystkich pa≈Ñstw. Koterie Wygna≈Ñcze nimi nie sƒÖ. StƒÖd masz mo≈ºliwo≈õƒá obej≈õcia prawa. Co powiesz na to? Nie czu≈Ç ≈ºadnych drga≈Ñ i odg≈Ços√≥w, ≈õwiadczƒÖcych o tym, ≈ºe urzƒÖdzenie faktycznie funkcjonuje. Wierzy≈Ç jednak wstƒôpnej ekspertyzie, kt√≥rƒÖ prowadzi≈Ç Fin. Zabra≈Ç d≈Ço≈Ñ i odwr√≥ci≈Ç siƒô w stronƒô Eliasa: - Sprowad≈∫ mojƒÖ ekipƒô jak najszybciej- powiedzia≈Ç archeolog, podchodzƒÖc do dyrektora.- Marika Anabell i Sung Kim Hee powinni byƒá ju≈º na Keplerze, gdy≈º przybyli wraz ze mnƒÖ. Udostƒôpnijcie r√≥wnie≈º transportowiec, gdy≈º trzeba bƒôdzie przewie≈∫ƒá nasz sprzƒôt oraz ludzi, kt√≥rzy zajmƒÖ siƒô d≈∫wiganiem go. Resztƒô powiadom najlepiej astrophonem. Gdy tylko bƒôdƒô mia≈Ç ju≈º niezbƒôdne minimum, od razu zabieram siƒô do pracy. Zbyt du≈ºo czasu zmarnowano na, wybacz, ≈ºe to m√≥wiƒô, na czcze badania. - Wybaczam- kiwnƒÖ≈Ç g≈ÇowƒÖ Elias, otwierajƒÖc tablicƒô dotykowƒÖ, kt√≥rƒÖ dosta≈Ç od Wƒôgra.- Osobi≈õcie siƒô tym zajmƒô i to zaraz. Zostawiam ciebie i artefakt sam na sam. Powodzenia. - Dziƒôki- skinƒÖ≈Ç g≈ÇowƒÖ Janos. - Mo≈ºe masz ju≈º jakie≈õ przeb≈Çyski geniuszu, co to mo≈ºe byƒá?- zapyta≈Ç jeszcze dyrektor, otwierajƒÖc wrota. - Nie, ale‚Ä¶- Janos spojrza≈Ç raz jeszcze na artefakt.- Mam wra≈ºenie, ≈ºe gdzie≈õ co≈õ podobnego widzia≈Çem, ale nie jestem w stanie przypomnieƒá gdzie i w jaki≈õ okoliczno≈õciach. - Hm, rozumiem- kiwnƒÖ≈Ç g≈ÇowƒÖ Elias.- Przypadki zwykle sƒÖ poczƒÖtkiem czego≈õ wielkiego. - ≈ªeby≈õ wiedzia≈Ç- za≈õmia≈Ç siƒô cicho archeolog.

item.title: Zapomniane dziedzictwo gminy Suchy Las
item.dc:creator: apialewska
item.content:encoded: ‚ÄûArcheologia tak jak inne nauki spo≈Çeczne, winna bowiem sprostaƒá nie tylko wymogom ≈õcis≈Ço≈õci naukowej, lecz tak≈ºe wyj≈õƒá naprzeciw potrzebom i oczekiwaniom spo≈Çecznym, budziƒá zainteresowanie i poczucie identyfikacji z deklarowanymi warto≈õciami (...) Zadaniem archeologii jest nadawanie znaczenia informacyjnego otaczajƒÖcym nas materialnym ≈õwiadectwom przesz≈Ço≈õci.‚Äù Stanis≈Çaw Tabaczy≈Ñski   Obiekt, kt√≥ry przedstawiƒô, tj. ko≈õci√≥≈Ç p.w. ≈õwiƒôtego Jana Chrzciciela jest bez wƒÖtpienia jednym z najwa≈ºniejszych element√≥w dziedzictwa¬† regionu gminy Suchy Las. Jego znaczenie jest o tyle symboliczne, ≈ºe w specyficznym krajobrazie, jakim jest poligon w Biedrusku stanowi jedynƒÖ widocznƒÖ pozosta≈Ço≈õƒá po zamieszkujƒÖcych niegdy≈õ ten teren ludziach. Bowiem zar√≥wno Chojnica jak i szereg innych wsi ( np.≈Åagiewniki, Glinno, Glinienko , Okolewa, Knyszyna, Trzustkowo i Tworkowo) ju≈º nie istniejƒÖ. Zosta≈Çy wch≈Çoniƒôte przez teren poligonu, a ich mieszka≈Ñcy wysiedleni. Historia osadnictwa na tych terenach siƒôga co najmniej czas√≥w ≈õredniowiecza. Historia ko≈õcio≈Ça p.w ≈õwiƒôtego Jana chrzciciela w Chojnicy Od najdawniejszych czas√≥w Suchy Las nale≈ºa≈Ç (obok ≈Åagiewnik, Glinna, Radojewa i Moraska) do parafii Chojnica. Data powstania parafii w Chojnicy nie jest dok≈Çadnie znana, w dokumentach ko≈õcielnych przyjmuje siƒô, ≈ºe parafia Chojnica by≈Ça erygowana w XI ‚Äì XII wieku, a ko≈õci√≥≈Ç p.w. ≈õw. Jana Chrzciciela (wspominany w ≈∫r√≥d≈Çach przed rokiem 1374) istnia≈Ç byƒá mo≈ºe ju≈º w XI wieku.¬† Chojnica stanowi≈Ça o≈õrodek opola jako osada posiadajƒÖca ko≈õci√≥≈Ç parafialny. W 1507 roku jednowioskowƒÖ parafiƒô w Morasku z≈ÇƒÖczono z parafiƒÖ Chojnica. Po przy≈ÇƒÖczeniu Moraska, do parafii chojnickiej nale≈ºa≈Ço 11 wsi. W 1531 w Chojnicy rozpoczƒô≈Ça siƒô budowa murowanego ko≈õcio≈Ça p.w. ≈õw. Jana Chrzciciela¬† przez Jana Przec≈Çawskiego, dziedzica wsi.¬† W 1556¬† uko≈Ñczono budowƒô ko≈õcio≈Ça w Chojnicy. By≈Ça to budowla jednonawowa w stylu p√≥≈∫nogotyckim. Od p√≥≈Çnocy dobudowana zosta≈Ça zakrystia oraz kaplica, za≈õ na naro≈ºnikach fasady zachodniej dwie okrƒÖg≈Çe wie≈ºyczki. Nad g≈Ç√≥wnym wej≈õciem widnia≈Ç herb Na≈Çƒôcz i data 1546r, kt√≥ry siƒô nie zachowa≈Ç. Z kolei na skarpie po≈Çudniowo-wschodniej dalej mo≈ºna podziwiaƒá herb Ryby. W nawie znajdowa≈Ço siƒô sklepienie gwia≈∫dziste o rze≈∫bionych wspornikach, dwug≈Çowe or≈Çy i ornament lwa czeskiego, z doby Wac≈Çawa II (1300r.). W latach 1720-1748 dokonano przebudowy¬† ko≈õcio≈Ça w stylu barokowym, m.in. wzniesiono kaplicƒô, przebudowano zakrystiƒô, wykonano wej≈õcie zachodnie, przemurowano okna zmieniajƒÖc ich kszta≈Çt. W XIX wieku dokonano kilku konserwacji i remont√≥w ko≈õcio≈Ça. W roku 1898 Gustaw von Treskow, jeden z najwiƒôkszych posiadaczy ziemskich w okolicach Poznania¬† sprzeda≈Ç Chojnice z przeznaczeniem na poligon szkoleniowy armii pruskiej, od kt√≥rej przejƒô≈Ça go w 1918 armia polska.   W okresie miƒôdzywojennym ka≈ºdy proboszcz parafii Chojnica by≈Ç jednocze≈õnie kapelanem dla Garnizonu Biedrusko. W niedzielƒô stacjonujƒÖce na poligonie jednostki wojskowe w zwartym szyku maszerowa≈Çy na tzw. ‚ÄûPolankƒô‚Äù, aby wziƒÖƒá udzia≈Ç w mszy ≈õw. Po zajƒôciu Polski w≈Çadze niemieckie postanowi≈Çy powiƒôkszyƒá obszar poligonu Biedrusko wcielajƒÖc do niego w 1943 roku Chojnicƒô, ≈Åagiewniki, Glinno, Glinienko i Okolewo. Do ko≈õcio≈Ça w Chojnicy mogli uczƒôszczaƒá tylko mieszka≈Ñcy powiƒôkszonego poligonu .W miƒôdzyczasie w≈Çadze niemieckie zamknƒô≈Çy cmentarz w Chojnicy a po wojnie (1946) polskie w≈Çadze wojskowe przystƒÖpi≈Çy do wysiedlania ludno≈õci cywilnej z Chojnicy, ≈Åagiewnik, Glinna, Glinienka i Okolewa. Domy oraz zabudowania gospodarcze zosta≈Çy rozebrane, a ceg≈Çƒô uzyskanƒÖ z rozbi√≥rki budynk√≥w przeznaczono na budowƒô nowej szko≈Çy. Na poligonie pozosta≈Ç pusty ko≈õci√≥≈Ç, nieu≈ºywany i niekonserwowany, powoli zamieniajƒÖcy siƒô w ruinƒô. Wszelkie pro≈õby do Wojew√≥dzkiego Konserwatora Zabytk√≥w o zabezpieczenie ko≈õcio≈Ça i uchronienie go przed dalszƒÖ dewastacjƒÖ pozostawa≈Çy bez odpowiedzi. Dopiero lata 90-te przynios≈Çy dzia≈Çania w celu zabezpieczenia ko≈õcio≈Ça przed ostatecznym zniszczeniem, kt√≥re ograniczy≈Çy siƒô jednak jedynie do wstawienia metalowych krat w oknach. Obok ko≈õcio≈Ça, od co najmniej 1546 roku (w√≥wczas zaczƒôto prowadziƒá ksiƒôgi parafialne) funkcjonowa≈Ç cmentarz. W latach 70-tych w≈Çadze komunalne mia≈Çy zamiar ekshumowaƒá cia≈Ça os√≥b tam pogrzebanych a szczƒÖtki przewie≈∫ƒá na cmentarz komunalny w Poznaniu. Jednak dziƒôki protestom mieszka≈Ñc√≥w, Gminnego Komitetu FJN oraz poparciu Komendy Poligonu Biedrusko cmentarz pozosta≈Ç.   Poligon w Biedrusku Choƒá w zachodniej czƒô≈õci Biedruska znajduje siƒô zamkniƒôty poligon, bƒôdƒÖcy pod administracjƒÖ Centrum Szkolenia Wojsk LƒÖdowych w Poznaniu, wiele teren√≥w nale≈ºƒÖcych w przesz≈Ço≈õci do wojska zosta≈Ço przejƒôte przez Gminƒô Suchy Las. Obecnie miejscowo≈õƒá ta objƒôta jest programem rewitalizacji obszar√≥w powojskowych na lata 2010-2018. Obecne plany zak≈ÇadajƒÖ, by Biedrusko mia≈Ço charakter miejscowo≈õci turystyczno - rekreacyjnej. Aby to zmieniƒá, gmina Suchy Las postanowi≈Ça zagospodarowaƒá tereny powojskowe. W 1995 roku poligon, ≈ÇƒÖki, lasy, jeziora zosta≈Çy objƒôte ochronƒÖ i utworzono Obszar Chronionego Krajobrazu Biedrusko. Ca≈Ço≈õƒá w≈ÇƒÖczona zosta≈Ça do europejskiej sieci ekologicznej Natura 2000 jako specjalny obszar ochrony siedlisk.   Obiekty zabytkowe Biedruska ujƒôte zosta≈Çy w ewidencji konserwatorskiej ‚ÄûZgodnie z zapisami studium uwarunkowa≈Ñ i kierunk√≥w zagospodarowania przestrzennego gminy Suchy Las korzystanie przez wojsko z teren√≥w poligonu powinno uwzglƒôdniaƒá nie tylko minimalizacjƒô zagro≈ºe≈Ñ istniejƒÖcych warto≈õci zasob√≥w dziedzictwa kulturowego, ale poprzez dzia≈Çania gminy zmierzajƒÖce do odrestaurowania i rehabilitacji obszar√≥w zdegradowanych i obiekt√≥w, powinna NastƒÖpiƒá poprawa stanu i funkcjonowania ≈õrodowiska kulturowego.‚Äù   ‚ÄûW miejscowych planach zagospodarowania przestrzennego dla miejscowo≈õci Biedrusko rownie≈º okre≈õlono obszary oraz obiekty, kt√≥re podlegajƒÖ zasadom ochrony ≈Çadu przestrzennego, ochrony ≈õrodowiska, przyrody i krajobrazu kulturowego, ochrony dziedzictwa kulturowego i zabytk√≥w oraz d√≥br kultury wsp√≥≈Çczesnej.‚Äù   ‚ÄûWarto≈õci i zasoby ≈õrodowiska kulturowego podlegajƒÖ opiece i ochronie ‚Äìzgodnie z ustawƒÖ o ochronie zabytk√≥w i opiece nad zabytkami z 2003 r.‚Äù     Jednak ko≈õci√≥≈Ç w Chojnicy, ani tereny nie istniejƒÖcych ju≈º miejscowo≈õci, podlegajƒÖcych niegdy≈õ tej parafii nie wystƒôpujƒÖ w ewidencji konserwatorskiej. Cze≈õƒá zabytk√≥w znajdujƒÖcych siƒô w ko≈õciele uda≈Ço siƒô uratowaƒá np. pochodzƒÖcƒÖ z 1554 gotyckƒÖ monstrancjƒô z postaciami ≈õw. Wojciecha i ≈õw. Stanis≈Çawa ufundowanƒÖ przez Andrzeja Przec≈Çawskiego (obecnie znajdujƒÖcƒÖ siƒô w Muzeum Archidiecezjalnym w Poznaniu), czy jeden z najciekawszych obiekt√≥w polskiego manieryzmu, czyli nagrobek Przec≈Çawskich, wykonany przez nieznanego mistrza., przeniesiony do Katedry w Poznaniu.   Public Archaeology i ko≈õci√≥≈Ç w Chojnicach Obecnie na zachodzie Europy oraz w Stanach Zjednoczonych nadal utrzymuje siƒô trend zwiƒÖzany z tzw. Public Archaeology. Jest to kierunek, traktujƒÖcy archeologiƒô jako jednƒÖ z¬† nauk spo≈Çecznych. Jej g≈Ç√≥wnym celem jest wzbudzenie zainteresowania oraz zaanga≈ºowania ¬†spo≈Çecze≈Ñstwa w kwestie zwiƒÖzane z¬† dziedzictwem archeologicznym. W duchu tej koncepcji czƒôsto z inicjatywy lokalnych spo≈Çeczno≈õci, z publicznych ≈õrodk√≥w finansuje siƒô projekty, kt√≥re inaczej nie zyska≈Çyby poparcia w≈õr√≥d odpowiednich instytucji. W Polsce r√≥wnie≈º, coraz czƒô≈õciej pojawiajƒÖ siƒô¬† inicjatywy zwiƒÖzane z archeologiƒÖ zaanga≈ºowanƒÖ. Poligon w Biedrusku posiada ogromny potencja≈Ç turystyczny, kt√≥ry m√≥g≈Çby okazaƒá siƒô ratunkiem dla znajdujƒÖcych siƒô tam zabytk√≥w takich jak ko≈õci√≥≈Ç w Chojnicy. Dziƒôki tego typu inicjatywom archeologia mo≈ºe spe≈Çniƒá¬† sw√≥j najwa≈ºniejszy obowiƒÖzek wzglƒôdem spo≈Çecze≈Ñstwa czyli ‚Äûnadawanie znaczenia informacyjnego otaczajƒÖcym nas materialnym ≈õwiadectwom przesz≈Ço≈õci‚Äù i jest to moim zdaniem najlepsza forma promocji.   Trudno, jednakowo≈º oceniƒá skutki ochrony archeologicznej i konserwatorskiej obiektu, kt√≥ry w zasadzie nigdy takowej nie podlega≈Ç. Z pewno≈õciƒÖ samo uchronienie jedynego zabytku ≈õwiadczƒÖcego o stuleciach ludzkiej egzystencji na tym terenie od ca≈Çkowitego zniszczenia, by≈Çoby pozytywnym efektem. Umieszczenie ko≈õcio≈Ça w Chojnicy na mapie parku krajobrazowego w Biedrusku z pewno≈õciƒÖ uatrakcyjni≈Çaby √≥w park dla turyst√≥w, a po≈õrednim skutkiem m√≥g≈Çby staƒá siƒô wzrost ≈õwiadomo≈õci spo≈Çecznej na temat dziedzictwa regionu. Potencjalne zagro≈ºenia, sƒÖ zwiƒÖzane z nieuniknionymi nastƒôpstwami turystyki, czyli degradacjƒÖ krajobrazu naturalnego i kulturowego.     Dorota Ga≈ÇƒÖzkowska

item.title: Day of Archaeology al Museo Nazionale "Giovanni Antonio Sanna di Sassari"
item.dc:creator: m.giorgio
item.content:encoded: Il Museo Nazionale Archeologico ed Etnografico ‚ÄúGiovanni Antonio Sanna‚Äù di Sassari √® un organismo polivalente, nato in seguito alle donazioni del Senatore sassarese Giovanni Antonio Sanna. A queste si sono aggiunte nuove collezioni grazie all'istituzione della Soprintendenza Archeologica del territorio e a successive prestigiose donazioni. Lavorare all‚Äôinterno del Museo significa dare voce ai suoi reperti e trasmettere al pubblico, attraverso un contatto diretto, il lavoro e gli studi portati avanti dai nostri colleghi archeologi che hanno lavorato sugli scavi e hanno studiato i materiali prima che questi trovassero spazio nell‚Äôesposizione museale. Negli ultimi anni ci siamo occupati prevalentemente di didattica, comunicazione e attivit√† legate alla conoscenza, conservazione e valorizzazione della collezione. La collezione √® stata fatta conoscere al pubblico sia con questi nuovi sistemi di comunicazione che con visite guidate gratuite. La didattica ci ha consentito di avvicinare al Museo fasce di pubblico sempre pi√π ampie ed eterogenee: i laboratori proposti hanno coinvolto soprattutto bambini dai 6 ai 12 anni, accompagnati dagli insegnanti e dai genitori, ma non sono mancate le occasioni in cui questi siano stati aperti a tutte le fasce di et√†. Le attivit√† pi√π richieste dal pubblico sono state lo scavo simulato e la manipolazione dell‚Äôargilla per la creazione di piccoli vasi. Grande successo ha riscosso anche il laboratorio ‚ÄúVietato non toccare‚Äù organizzato nell‚Äôambito della giornata delle disabilit√†: i visitatori sono stati bendati e hanno avuto la possibilit√† di conoscere la collezione del museo utilizzando solo i sensi del tatto e dell‚Äôolfatto. La comunicazione ci ha visti impegnati in vari settori: dalla realizzazione di didascalie e pannelli per mostre temporanee, alla produzione di comunicati stampa per la pubblicizzazione dei vari eventi. Un settore che ha richiesto grande impegno √® stato quello connesso alla promozione attraverso l'uso dei social network: in collaborazione con la direttrice del Museo abbiamo creato gli account facebook, twitter, instagram, pinterest e youtube (questi ultimi, in verit√†, fermi da un po' di tempo). Questo ci ha consentito di avere notevole visibilit√†, accrescendo il numero dei visitatori e rafforzando il rapporto con l‚Äôutenza. Ci√≤ ha portato ad un maggiore interesse della comunit√† locale nei confronti del Museo; si sono cos√¨ moltiplicate, al contempo, le iniziative in collaborazione con altri enti e associazioni e le attivit√† di formazione di tirocinanti universitari e delle scuole secondarie di secondo grado. Ogni giorno, infatti, ospitiamo tirocinanti dell‚ÄôUniversit√† di Sassari e studenti delle scuole superiori impegnati in progetti di Alternanza Scuola-Lavoro, contribuendo in maniera attiva alla loro formazione specifica. Per permettere di comunicare e vivere il Museo nella sua interezza e per portare avanti il suo ruolo didattico e divulgativo vengono, inoltre, organizzate numerose conferenze scientifico-divulgative, workshop, eventi teatrali e canori che consentono un maggiore coinvolgimento e gradimento del pubblico. Notevole √® stato anche il lavoro di studio che ci ha portato a conoscere i diversi reperti esposti e quelli presenti nei magazzini, utilizzati talvolta in esposizioni temporanee. Questo lavoro ci ha permesso anche di collaborare con altri archeologi che spesso frequentano il Museo per studio, contribuendo a creare un clima di confronto costruttivo e crescita professionale. Costante √® stata anche la collaborazione con i restauratori che sono prontamente intervenuti per preservare i materiali dai danni provocati dallo scorrere del tempo. Il nostro Day of Archaeology 2017 di quest‚Äôanno √® stata, quindi, un‚Äôordinaria giornata di lavoro in cui abbiamo conciliato un po‚Äô tutte le attivit√† sopra descritte. Ma √® stato per noi anche l‚Äôoccasione per celebrare chi ha reso il Museo Sanna ci√≤ che √® oggi: il professor Ercole Contu che agli inizi degli anni ‚Äô70 del secolo scorso ha riallestito il museo nella veste ancora visibile, attraverso l‚Äôidea di un museo didattico alla portata di tutti e comprensibile a tutti, un museo che divenisse perno della divulgazione archeologica e meta di scuole e visitatori italiani e stranieri, oltre che di specialisti del settore. A fine pomeriggio, quindi, il professor Ercole Contu √® stato nostro ospite per presentare il suo ultimo volume ‚ÄúUn drink al nuraghe‚Äù, edito presso la Carlo Delfino editore e presentato dal dott. Pasquale Porcu, in cui viene raccontata la storia del vino antico nei i suoi aspetti materiali e nei suoi risvolti culturali e spirituali. Il nostro Day of Archaeology 2017 √® stata, infine, una lunga giornata perch√© il Museo Sanna √® stato aperto in maniera straordinaria sino alle 23:00, inaugurando in questa maniera una serie di aperture straordinarie serali estive che permetteranno ai visitatori di vivere e visitare il museo anche nelle ore pi√π fresche dell‚Äôestate.

item.title: NICK THE LOCK‚ÄôS COTTAGE
item.dc:creator: millsr
item.content:encoded: There is much mirth amongst the diggers. Two babies‚Äô comforters, a plastic joke beard, a sponge rubber cushion, a Marathon wrapper (the antecedent of the Snickers chocolate bar), several crisp packets, a car choke cable‚Ä¶the artefacts found in our uppermost deposit were a mixed lot. But a Marathon wrapper provides an opportunity to introduce the idea of terminus post quem and terminus ante quem to my volunteer novice archaeologists, since it must have been discarded before 1990, when the much-lamented name change took place. Crisp packets, too, bear ‚Äòbest-by‚Äô dates, telling us approximately when earthworms tugged them into the soil. We are experiencing a little contemporary archaeology as we investigate what is a very public site, a few metres from the towpath of the Monmouthshire and Brecon Canal, south-west of Cwmbran, Wales. The Mon&Brec silted weedily into obscurity in the 1930s, as a last trickle of freight it carried finally dried up and, unable to compete with rail and road transport, it was abandoned by its owner, the Great Western Railway. At the same time, Richard Williams, ‚ÄúNick the Lock‚Äù as he was known by locals, lock-keeper of the Ty Coch flight of nine locks, settled into retirement, having spent 40-odd years ensuring that the stretch of waterway in his charge contained enough water to allow the passage of barges travelling south to Newport or north through what was still a busy industrial area of south Monmouthshire, crammed with collieries, iron works, brick and lime kilns, tinplate factories and stone quarries. The canal quickly became derelict. Williams, however, continued to live in the lock keeper‚Äôs cottage, which stood beside Shop Lock, once the site of a canal-side workshop. After his death, his daughter(s) stayed on, until their isolated home was demolished in the 1950s, its stone reused by a nearby farmer. Over 60 years later, several of the locks at Ty Coch have been restored in a four-year ‚ÄúWaterworks‚Äù paject, a partnership between the Monmouthshire, Brecon and Abergavenny Canal Trust and Torfaen Borough Council. Every recent summer I haved joined in, working alongside and leading groups of volunteers from the Waterway Recovery Group. As I wandered about the work sites, with their spreads of dredged-up silt, disturbed soil and rubble, I would pick up significant numbers of fragments of nineteenth- and early twentieth-century ceramics (Figure 1). The scatter was over a considerable area and around several locks. This presence of a spread of fragmentary material echoed something I‚Äôd noticed on other canals and other locks, for example the Swansea Canal further west in Wales and the Stover Canal in Devon. I imagine these deposits are due to the practice of spreading ‚Äúnight soil,‚Äù the contents of privies, as fertiliser. Privies were convenient places to dispose of ashes and other domestic waste, including broken crockery, but since they were ‚Äòdry,‚Äô there being no mains sewerage nor piped water, they would have to be regularly emptied, and in isolated spots such as Ty Coch the nearby vegetable garden would be the logical and useful place to do this. [caption id="attachment_29320" align="aligncenter" width="733"] Figure 1: Artefacts from disturbed soils at Ty Coch.[/caption] Williams was the last of a profession that had cared for the Ty Coch locks since they opened for their first barges in 1796. The spread of material appeared to match this continuous occupation. But where had it originated? When the restoration scheme began there was no trace of either workshop or cottage, though both were shown on OS maps (Figure 2). An excavation in 2013 (Burchell ND) revealed the plan of the workshop, together with a fine sawpit. A small trench dug in 2014 located a wall. However a few cm of wall does not a cottage make! With the encouragement of the on-site team I proposed an archaeological investigation to firmly pinpoint the site of the lock-keeper‚Äôs cottage and to learn as much as possible about the lives of Nick the Lock and his predecessors. [caption id="attachment_29321" align="aligncenter" width="553"] Figure 2: 1890s Ordnance Survey map showing buildings to west of Shop Lock, Ty Coch.[/caption] That two-week excavation ended, at least for 2017, on the Day of Archaeology. It coincided with the end of the Waterworks project. Carried out entirely by Waterway Recovery Group volunteers, the excavation revealed the northern part of the cottage, with north, east and western walls. Cut into the sloping ground on the north side we found what was probably a kitchen, with a partially-blocked fireplace, perhaps backing a range (Figure 3). On the west side there was a passage floored with bricks and flagstones, and a small cast-iron drain cover (Figure 4). This may not have been roofed. [caption id="attachment_29322" align="aligncenter" width="1184"] Figure 3: Fireplace in north wall of cottage.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_29323" align="aligncenter" width="888"] Figure 4: Passage on west side of cottage, looking north.[/caption] The cottage‚Äôs outer walls were constructed using large ashlar stone blocks that appear to have been re-used, either from left-over canal construction material or perhaps had been quarried from the nearby Cistercian abbey at Llantarnam. Internal walls were also mostly of stone, but used smaller blocks, with a rubble infill. All the internal walls were faced, at least at their base, with a thick skim of lime cement. The internal floors were also of lime cement, with occasional flagstones. Doorways had stone steps. When the north wall was built, the construction trench was backfilled using what looks like clinker, large lumps of slag, and numerous roof tiles, some of which were stamped ‚ÄúSealy‚Äôs Patent,‚Äù suggesting a source constructed after 1843. The abundant burnt material could have come from the adjacent workshop, which may have forged its own ironwork and possibly housed a steam-powered saw. The roof tiles support the suggestion that the cottage we excavated was the second on the site, replacing a building dating from the 1840s. The later cottage was roofed in slate. Unlike the nearby open areas, not many artefacts were found associated directly with the cottage. The topsoil entertained us with its mix of plastic, beer cans, crisp packets, car parts, toy plastic soldiers, an umbrella, milk bottles and the like, much of it dating from the 1980s. Other deposits contained small amounts of nineteenth century ceramics, but did not match the concentration of material present just 20m to the south. We have so far located about a third of the cottage. The southern part may have been completely robbed away, but there are tantalising indications of external features on both east and west sides. So, for once, on the last-ever Day of Archaeology, I was actually doing real archaeology ‚Äì some 60-odd guests invited to the celebration to mark the end of the Waterworks project can vouch for that (Wigmore 2017)! I must acknowledge the commitment, hard work and enthusiasm of the Waterway Recovery Group volunteers, most of whom had to climb a steep archaeological learning curve as well as acquire blisters! Both the Trust and Torfaen council are keen to carry out more work, and to expose and conserve the cottage remains, so I hope that we may learn yet more about the home of Nick the Lock. Ralph Mills   References Burchell, R. ND. An Archaeological Report on an excavation at Shop Lock Ty Coch. http://media.wix.com/ugd/90e7f0_00af16ceaf174c7689d9824ea37cab70.pdf Wigmore, Sarah, 2017. Special ceremony to commemorate Monmouthshire and Brecon Canal restoration. South Wales Argus web site. 28th July. http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/15441511.Special_ceremony_to_commemorate_Monmouthshire_and_Brecon_Canal_restoration/

item.title: La comunicaci√≥n como herramienta para concienciar sobre la necesidad de preservar el patrimonio arqueol√≥gico
item.dc:creator: mlaw
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_29369" align="aligncenter" width="2464"] Elisa Pereira (Asociaci√≥n Costa dos Castros)[/caption]   En la Asociaci√≥n Costa dos Castros desarrollamos distintas actividades orientadas hacia el conocimiento, la puesta en valor y difusi√≥n del importante patrimonio arqueol√≥gico que existe en el municipio de Oia (Galicia-Espa√±a). Para ello, programamos iniciativas que van desde intervenciones arqueol√≥gicas y acciones divulgativas hasta campa√±as de comunicaci√≥n a trav√©s de diversos canales. Este esfuerzo en materia de comunicaci√≥n persigue varios objetivos, entre los que destacan: -Difundir la riqueza patrimonial de Oia. -Visibilizar el compromiso con el patrimonio que mantienen las comunidades de montes vecinales en mano com√∫n que forman parte de la Asociaci√≥n. -Sensibilizar a la sociedad sobre la necesidad de preservar los bienes arqueol√≥gicos. Para ello, realizamos publicaciones en redes sociales, actualizaciones en nuestro blog www.costadoscastros.com, difundimos notas de prensa y mantenemos relaciones fluidas con los medios de comunicaci√≥n, entre otras iniciativas. Como ejemplo de este esfuerzo en el campo de la comunicaci√≥n, el D√≠a de la Arqueolog√≠a (el pasado 28 de julio) un diario local publicaba un reportaje sobre una de nuestras √∫ltimas actuaciones: unos trabajos de limpieza de vegetaci√≥n con control arqueol√≥gico en una zona de monte comunal (O Viveiro) que alberga una gran cantidad de petroglifos. La actuaci√≥n arqueol√≥gica, promovida por la Comunidad de Montes Vecinales en Mano Com√∫n de Pedornes y financiada a trav√©s de una campa√±a de crowdfunding, ha supuesto mejoras en la accesibilidad y seguridad de la zona, al tiempo que ha permitido localizar 9 grabados hasta el momento desconocidos.   Con motivo de estos trabajos de limpieza, que han estado supervisados por la arque√≥loga Elisa Pereira, tambi√©n se ha analizado el estado actual de los distintos grabados. Entre ellos destaca el panel rupestre conocido como Auga dos Cebros: el √∫nico petroglifo conocido en la Europa atl√°ntica donde aparece representada una embarcaci√≥n de tipolog√≠a mediterr√°nea del segundo milenio antes de Cristo. Se trata de un elemento excepcional y de gran fragilidad que es necesario preservar para que las pr√≥ximas generaciones puedan seguir disfrutando de √©l. A trav√©s de la difusi√≥n de este tipo de contenidos en las redes sociales, medios de comunicaci√≥n y visitas guiadas en grupos reducidos queremos concienciar a la sociedad sobre la importancia de conocer, respetar y cuidar este legado milenario. Es decir, creemos en la comunicaci√≥n como herramienta para convertir a vecinos y visitantes en aut√©nticos guardianes del patrimonio.

item.title: LES RUPESTRES 2.0: Une vision artistique de l'arch√©ologie
item.dc:creator: mlaw
item.content:encoded:
By Catherine Vasseur Je suis photographe amateur et passionn√©e d'histoire. Par ces photos, j'ai voulu cr√©er un pont entre la vie humaine avant J-C soit 36000 ans et notre vie en 2017. Avec des tissus d'aujourd'hui, du plastique et un ordinateur, j'invente ma propre perception de l'arch√©ologie avec mes √©motions, ma r√©flexion, mon v√©cu. Enfant, j'accompagnais mes parents lors de fouilles gallo-romaines √† Saint-Paul-Trois-Ch√¢teaux (Dr√¥me-France). Je grimpais la colline pour chercher les dents de requins...
En toute humilit√©, bien s√ªr,
Je me suis inspir√©e de la Restitution de la Caverne du Pont d'Arc (Ard√®che-France).
Je vous remercie de me lire,
Cordialement,
Catherine
